Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society objected to the the university's invitation of Harvey to deliver a commencement speech because of Harvey's views on abortion. Harvey withdrew from delivering the speech.
Public Response: Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. The interim president stated: "We had hoped very much that he would take part in our commencement exercises, but we respect his wishes . . . To my knowledge, Paul Harvey withdrew from the invitation to be our commencement speaker for personal reasons, but has agreed to come to our campus at a later date to participate in a fund-raising activity or other event to honor his longtime friend Joe Bonansinga."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The college informed students that the play could not be performed on campus and banned the performance.

During a commencement speech, students heckled Hedges, rushed the podium, and unplugged his microphone, objecting to Hedges' anti-war views. After briefly addressing the audience on the importance of academic freedom and Hedge's right to offer his opinion, the college president suggested that Hedges end his speech early for his own protection. Hedges was then escorted off the stage by campus security guards.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. During the disruption, the president of the college took the microphone and said: "If you wish to protest the speaker's remarks, I would ask that you would do it in silence, as some were doing in the back. That is perfectly appropriate. But he has the right to offer this opinion here, and we would like him to continue with his remarks." Afterwards he told reporters: I don't apologize for the fact that I let Mr. Hedges continue to speak after he was stopped the first time and for the statement that I made to allow that to go forward. I do apologize for the fact that for all kinds of reasons this turned into not a celebration of their [the students'] achievements and a reflection on the mark they might make in the world but became really an example of, I think, just the sort of unfortunate state of our conversations in this society about war."

Controversy Explanation: A student threw a pie at Sharansky during his speech, objecting to Sharansky's pro-Palestinian views. Sharansky spoke despite the pie-throwing.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the college president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the college president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Students and faculty petitioned the university to rescind its invitation of Santorum to deliver a commencement speech because of Santorum's negative comments about homosexuality. Some students walked out during his speech but no major disruptions occurred.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. A spokesperson reported on the Trustees reasoning as follows: “We're trying to send a message that all views are welcome here, regardless of their popularity. . . .This many not be a popular path, but if we stand for tolerance, we can’t be intolerant of anyone, and we hope all involved will keep that in mind.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society objected to the university's invitation of McLellan to deliver a commencement speech because of McLellan's views on abortion and stem cell research. McClellan spoke successfully.
Carty withdrew from delivering a commencement speech over corporate corruption concerns. Both Carty and the university claimed the decision was mutual.
Public Response: Encouraged (or approved of) Self-Censorship. A university spokesperson clarified that: “It was decided that in light of the recent developments, he [Carty] wouldn't be speaking at our commencement this year.”

The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Stanton to deliver a commencement speech because of Stanton's views on abortion and his support for assisted suicide. Stanton spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Foreign Affairs, Criminal or Other Misconduct
Controversy Explanation: College officials first said they wouldn't cancel an event featuring Ritter, then canceled the event, citing disruptions to school operations and the need to take extraordinary security measures after students opposed Ritter's speech. The students objected to Ritter because of his position on the Iraq War and a possible sexual scandal involving a minor.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A college trustee said: "Whether we agree with his [Ritter's] views, or whether we like him or not, the forum is the larger issue."

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The university canceled the event only days before dress rehearsal.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. In an email to the campus community the university president said: “In conscience, I cannot approve of its [the Vagina Monologues] performance on the campus. The play is offensive, questionable in its portrayal of violence, and not in keeping with the respect accorded the human body in this institution’s religious tradition."

A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.
The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind Matthews' invitation because of Matthews' views on abortion. Matthews spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Foreign Affairs, Criminal or Other Misconduct
Controversy Explanation: School administrators at other schools canceled Ritter's appearances due to outside complaints about Ritter's opposition to the Iraq War and possible illegal conduct with minors, but Washington College refused to disinvite him.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A college media relations specialist stated: "As an institute of higher learning, we have a duty to provide people with different points of view. . . .[Our decision is] not an endorsement of his activities. … We're just giving him a soapbox for two hours."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The university canceled the performance.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The university canceled the performance. The university then reversed its decision following a faculty member's offer to sponsor the performance as part of a course she was teaching, which the university president considered "a legitimate exercise of academic freedom," saying that putting the play on in a classroom placed it "in a suitable environment of debate and discussion.”
Public Response: Condemn Speaker (or Artist) as Person, Appeased Protesters. The university president said that "in choosing to cancel this production we believe the sensationalism surrounding the play stood in the way of our coming together to dialogue around the issue of violence against women."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Lawrence-Lightfoot to deliver a commencement speech because of Lawrence-Lightfoot's views on abortion. Lawrence-Lightfoot spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Cellucci to deliver a commencement speech because of Celllucci's views on abortion. Cellucci spoke successfully.
Hecklers booed Heaphy into silence during a commencement speech after Heaphy's remarks about the 9/11 attacks. Heaphy was unable to finish her speech.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person. The university president stated that "not only thoughtful but exceedingly responsible in today's world."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of O'Connor to deliver a commencement speech because of O'Connor's views on abortion. O'Connor spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of McCollum to deliver a commencement speech because of McCollum's views on abortion. McCollum spoke successfully.

The College of the Holy Cross' women's studies department rescinded Kissling's invitation after receiving pressure from the college president and outside groups who objected to Kissling's pro-choice views and her views on gender. Kissling and the event coordinators attempted to reschedule the event but the college did not allow her to speak on campus.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Encouraged (or approved of) Self-Censorship. The college president claimed to support "free speech" but denounced Kissling's criticisms of the Church as "strident, personal, manipulative, and unfair" and added that the women's department exercised "poor judgment" when it invited her to speak.

School: Georgetown University, Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service
Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Pelosi to deliver a commencement speech because of Pelosi's views on abortion. Pelosi spoke successfully.
Students and faculty demanded that the university disinvite Paulin, describing Paulin's views as anti-Israel. The English department revoked the invitation.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. A university statement pointed out that the invitation had been made "in ignorance of the views that he [Paulin] has expressed. . . . [T]he English department shares the concerns expressed [by the protesters]."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the university's selection of Yasin as a commencement speaker because of Yasin's views on Israel and Islam. Students protested but Yasin spoke without disruption.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  An article reported that "University faculty and officials defended the choice of Yasin’s speech, and decried the personal attacks made on him." The only public statement was by the head of the commencement committee who said about releasing the text of Yasin's speech in advance: “It’s never happened before. . . . I don't see why it should happen this time, unless the student orator wishes to release it.”

Controversy Explanation: The university rescinded its invitation of Goodwin to deliver a commencement speech after Goodwin admitted to committing plagiarism.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kaye to deliver a commencement speech because of Kaye's views on the status of frozen embryos. Kaye spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kaptur to deliver a commencement speech because of Kaptur's views on abortion. Kaptur spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion. Mitchell spoke successfully.

Students protested the college's invitation of Fleischer because of Fleischer's involvement with the Bush administration and the Iraq War. Many students protested during the event, and some were removed for heckling. The university stood firm in its commitment to free speech and did not take sides.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The college president said: "One of the most important functions for an institution of higher education is to provide a forum for reason, debate and discussion of controversial public issues . . ..[The university has] honored the principle of academic freedom . . . [that] includes, to be sure, the freedom of speech and it also observes the courtesy which is concomitant with that principle — that is the freedom to listen."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Panetta to deliver a commencement speech because of Panetta's views on abortion. Panetta spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Tubbs Jones to deliver a commencement speech because of Tubbs Jones' views on abortion. Tubbs Jones spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Political Views
Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty protested Bush's policies, such as the "redistribution of resources toward the wealthy." At the start of commencement, the associate vice president for student affairs warned those in attendance, "Disruption, including obstructing the view or hearing of others, will not be tolerated." As Bush was introduced and walking to the podium, about 10 people stood up and turned their backs to the stage, and police escorted some of them were escorted out of the ceremony.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An administrator said Bush was a “tireless worker in the field of education” and “a man who unified this country after the terrible events of 9/11.”

Controversy Explanation: The university administration canceled the first of two lectures by Poe after the Catholic League described her views as anti-Catholic.
The university administration canceled the second of two lectures by Poe after the Catholic League described her views as anti-Catholic.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Snelling to deliver a commencement speech because of Snelling's views on abortion. Snelling spoke successfully.

Students decried Rice's speaking invitation because of her involvement with the Bush administration and started a petition against her appearance at commencement. The event proceeded mostly without disruption.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Kirk Jr. to deliver a commencement speech because of Kirk Jr.'s views on abortion. Kirk Jr. spoke successfully.

Faculty members from the African-American studies department told local reporters they would not attend the commencement speech in protest of Giuliani's insensitivity to racial issues during his two terms as mayor of New York City. Giuliani spoke successfully over silent protests.

Students objected to Moseley's invitation, claiming Moseley was unqualified to deliver a commencement speech because he had dropped out of college to become a skier. The students lodged complaints with the university indicating they felt insulted that the university had not invited someone who had contributed more to society. Moseley spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A university speaker search consultant said: “His message as an Olympian will really resonate with students. He’s been skiing since he was 4 years old, and has an outstanding message about dedication and setting goals.”
